div.head: To the Welwillers of the Mathematicall Lecture T. Hood, wisheth all felicitie.
div.p:
IT is not vnknowen vnto you most friendlie and curteous auditors, that the worshipfull VVilliam Sanderson, besides the great coste, which hee hath heretofore imployed in the searching out of the Northwest passage vnto China, and the Moluccas, and to a relieued our countrimen in Virginia) hath nowe of late with no small charge for the farther honour and benefite of the commonwealth caused twoo Globes (the Celestiall and the Terrestriall) to be set foorth. And for somuch as the
Globes of themselues without their vse (which is most singular of all other Mathematicall instrumentes) are more delightfull to the eie then profitable to the professor thereof, he did with a friendlie consideratiō inuite me to pēne this treatise cōcerning their vse, the which I thought good generally to dedicate to the tuition of you al, rather then to any one (as the common vse is) in this respect. I am crediblie informed of late that certaine men, whereof one (how profoundly soeuer hee thinketh of his learning) not being hable ether to wright true English, or Latine, hath gone about to form an out rageous, and most impudent Pamphlet to my disgrace, & to commit it to the presse, an other not beyng hable either to write or reade, runneth vp & downe, both the Court, and Citie (pretending I know not
what skill in Mathematical matters) seeking to discredite al mē in respect of him selfe, & me not modestly among the rest. Forsomuch therfore (most louing auditors) as these men and such like without any cause (except my well doing mooue them thereunto) haue gone about to Kendell a most vile conceit against me in your mindes: my request therefore vnto you all is this, that you will friendly and fauorably peruse this worke: and conferring it with the profite which you haue acknow
• edged in my reading, vouchsafe to be my patrones against such vndeserued ill willers of mine, and that so much the rather, because in this Booke I haue sette foorth certaine things, whereof I haue not had any direction from other authors, but haue grounded them vppon mine owne studie, and experience guided
by reason, which if it shal please you to do, you shall finde me most willing, as I haue alwaies bin, to be profitable not to you onely priuately, but to my cōmon wealth publikely in what I may. Farewell.
